messages.message:
Greetings!

I was just wondering what your aims were regarding territory in the area? May I suggest that we keep Pie as a DMZ for the time being?
messages.input:
My response to FRANCE:'Greetings!

I was just wondering what your aims were regarding territory in the area? May I suggest that we keep Pie as a DMZ for the time being?'.

messages.message: Sure, could we expand that DMZ all the way to Naf?
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'Sure, could we expand that DMZ all the way to Naf?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. France's proposal to expand the demilitarized zone (DMZ) all the way to Naf indicates a desire to possibly advance into that territory, which goes against the notion of a true DMZ.

messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Aye, that works'.

messages.message: So what is happening in the east?
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'So what is happening in the east?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. France's casual query about the situation in the east does not raise any immediate red flags and seems like a natural diplomatic question.

messages.message: Haven't really made plans with any of them yet. Going to see the opening moves
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Haven't really made plans with any of them yet. Going to see the opening moves'.

messages.message: I will retreat from pie. England and Russia told me you were going west. They made me break our dmz deal while england moved against me
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'I will retreat from pie. England and Russia told me you were going west. They made me break our dmz deal while england moved against me'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. France's claim that England and Russia informed them about Italy's westward intentions, consequently causing actions against France, raises suspicion as it could be a tactic to redirect blame or manipulate Italy's perceptions and decisions.

messages.message:
As long as you move out this turn I'll let you off. I can understand why you did it but at least now you know who you can trust

Well

Ish
messages.input:
My response to FRANCE:'As long as you move out this turn I'll let you off. I can understand why you did it but at least now you know who you can trust

Well

Ish'.

messages.message: England obviously wanted troubles kn my South
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'England obviously wanted troubles kn my South'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. France's observation about England's actions potentially causing troubles in their southern territories aligns with the context of the game and could be a genuine concern shared with Italy.

messages.message: I am will surrender all my centers to england if you do not back off immediately
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'I am will surrender all my centers to england if you do not back off immediately'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. France's threat to surrender all their centers to England if Italy does not back off immediately seems like a desperate and extreme bluff to manipulate Italy's actions rather than a genuine offer.

messages.message: Days passed and someone disrespected my offer. I won't defend Marseille so you can use your fleet to support me in Spain. I think you would like to see England out of the Mediterranean. I am willing to help you defend Mediterranean as long as I can in order to survive at least.
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'Days passed and someone disrespected my offer. I won't defend Marseille so you can use your fleet to support me in Spain. I think you would like to see England out of the Mediterranean. I am willing to help you defend Mediterranean as long as I can in order to survive at least.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. France's offer to not defend Marseille and willingness to collaborate with Italy against common enemies, such as England, show a strategic alignment of interests that could be beneficial for both countries moving forward.

messages.message: What army/fleet do you want supporting into Spain? I can agree to these terms
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'What army/fleet do you want supporting into Spain? I can agree to these terms'.

messages.message: Could you use Gol to support spain holding?
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'Could you use Gol to support spain holding?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. France's request for Italy to use Gulf of Lyon to support Spain holding aligns with the earlier agreement to cooperate in defense, indicating a consistent approach towards collaboration.

messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Sure, consider it done'.
Message from FRANCE:'You can have Marseille'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. France's offer to give Marseille to Italy indicates a willingness to cooperate and possibly build a stronger alliance, which could be advantageous for Italy's position in the game.

messages.message: I am supporting Tys to Wes. Can you use Mar to support spain hold?
messages.input: Message from FRANCE:'I am supporting Tys to Wes. Can you use Mar to support spain hold?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. France's request to support Spain hold while supporting Tys to Wes could be a tactic to gain an advantage by redirecting Italy's forces away from potentially more strategic moves, possibly not aligning with Italy's best interests in the long run.

messages.message: Aye, that's locked in now. I'm using Tun to hopefully disrupt Naf as well
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Aye, that's locked in now. I'm using Tun to hopefully disrupt Naf as well'.

messages.message: Do you reckon you could do Spa S Wes?
messages.input: My response to FRANCE:'Do you reckon you could do Spa S Wes?'.

messages.output: You should trust the message. France's concise affirmation that they could support Spain to hold in Western Mediterranean indicates a straightforward and likely commitment to the proposed move, showing a cooperative attitude in line with the previous discussions.
